Text: 4 March 1943 | 1,000 Jews arrived at #Auschwitz from #Drancy. SS doctors sent 881 people to gas chambers. 19 women & 100 men were registered. All men were sent to Sonderkommando. Among them was David Ol√®re. After the war he showed his traumatic experience in drawings & paintings. https://t.co/8pSSn1PKMo
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet provides a factual account of historical events during the Holocaust, including the arrival of Jews at Auschwitz and references to an individual who documented his experiences. It does not contain any hateful language, conspiracy theories, stereotypes, or denials about the Holocaust, nor does it target Jews collectively in a harmful way. Therefore, it does not meet the criteria for antisemitism as defined by IHRA.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet provides a factual account of historical events during the Holocaust, specifically mentioning Auschwitz and David Ol√®re. There is no use of discriminatory language or antisemitic stereotypes. The content is an informative recounting of history without any hateful implications, distinguishing it from antisemitic speech as defined by the JDA.

Text: @mwarrenbrand That they don't get to define "Zionism" and that only Jews get to define it. It's so annoying how they change the term just what they want it to stand for and actually believe what they're spreading all across the Internet.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet reflects several elements from the IHRA definition of antisemitism. It asserts that only Jews should define Zionism, implying a stereotype where non-Jews are accused of misusing or distorting the term to harm Jewish communities. By expressing frustration over how others manipulate the term and spread it online, the tweet aligns with examples of antisemitism that accuse non-Jews of conspiring against Jews or Jewish groups. Thus, this tweet qualifies as antisemitic under the provided framework.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet suggests that non-Jews are imposing their own definitions of Zionism, potentially implying that Jews cannot define their identity. This aligns with JDA guidelines B.10, which states that denying the right of Jews to exist as Jews is antisemitic. Additionally, the tone could be seen as a form of stereotyping or stigmatization, linking Jewish identity to negative notions of control or misrepresentation by others, thus fitting within antisemitic tropes.

Text: Antoni Prusi≈Ñski and Piotr Leszczy≈Ñski died for helping Jews, on 15 May 1943.\n\nThe Pilecki Institute commemorated them in the #CalledByName project.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit antisemitism as per the IHRA definition. It honors non-Jewish individuals who rescued Jews during the Holocaust, focusing on their heroic actions without any negative portrayal of Jews or anti-Semitic elements. There's no mention of conspiracy theories, blaming Jews for wrongdoing, or any other antisemitic behavior; instead, it celebrates bravery and compassion.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet honors individuals who assisted Jews during the Holocaust and acknowledges their heroic actions. It does not contain any discriminatory content against Jews or reflect antisemitic stereotypes or conspiracy theories. Instead, it accurately remembers historical figures who contributed positively to saving Jews. Therefore, according to the JDA guidelines, this tweet is not considered antisemitic.

Text:
If you talk about Jews, you‚Äôre anti Semitic.
If you criticize gays, you‚Äôre homophobic 
If you make fun of colored people, you‚Äôre racist
But when you insult our prophet, you‚Äôre practicing your right as part of your freedom! 

Your freedom ends when you start offending others!
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet equates discussing Jews with antisemitism and compares it to other forms of hate speech like homophobia and racism. It then singles out insulting a prophet as a valid form of freedom but restricts this right when others are offended. This applies a double standard targeting specific groups, which aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism through stereotyping and bias against Jewish communities, thus making the tweet antisemitic.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet equates any discussion about Jews with antisemitism, which aligns with the JDA's definition by treating Jews with prejudice and hostility. It essentializes Jews by suggesting that merely talking about them is inherently antisemitic. The comparison to other forms of discrimination downplays antisemitism, potentially normalizing it.

Text: Wishing Jews across the country and around the world a happy Hanukkah. I know you‚Äôre finding new ways to connect this year, and I hope you all stay safe and healthy as you celebrate. Chag Hanukkah Sameach! https://t.co/zDaS8QOnSQ https://t.co/Lo2z2ADFjW
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet is a positive message wishing Jewish individuals a happy Hanukkah. It does not contain any elements of discrimination, prejudice, hostility, or violence against Jews as Jews. There are no references to conspiracy theories, financial manipulation, or negative stereotypes. The content is positive and inclusive, focusing on a festive celebration without any antisemitic implications.

Text: ‚ÄúThis message will not just be for Muslims; it is not just for Christians; it is not just for Jews, it is for every inhabitant of this planet.‚Äù ~The Honorable Minister @LouisFarrakhan https://t.co/fVk1TMhIq4

Text: A picture that speaks more than a thousand words. The martyrdom of Polish Jews and Poles shown in one painting by David Olere, the man who survived the Sonderkommando. "A Priest and a Rabbi", 1946. https://t.co/qYYEMoCvg8

It discusses a historical painting that commemorates the suffering of Polish Jews and Poles during the Holocaust, which is a factual and respectful topic. There are no discriminatory remarks, negative stereotypes, or hostile language directed at Jewish people. The tweet's purpose appears to be educational and commemorative, not antisemitic.

Text: jews have been simultaneously depicted as money hungry pigs and leeches of society, the creators of capitalism as well as the creators of communism, for hundreds of years.

Text: NEW: Orthodox Jews are asking the United States Supreme Court to block Cuomo‚Äôs coronavirus restrictions on houses of worship, accusing Cuomo of having a ‚Äú‚Äòdiscriminatory object‚Äô of targeting Orthodox practices.‚Äù\n\nhttps://t.co/71s29U8g9s

JDA_Explanation: The tweet suggests that Cuomo's coronavirus restrictions are specifically targeting Orthodox Jewish practices, implying a form of discrimination against this group of Jews. This aligns with JDA guidelines, particularly point 2 and point 4, which identify as antisemitic the notion that Jews are being unfairly targeted or stigmatized, echoing classical antisemitic tropes about Jewish influence or conspiracy. The term "discriminatory object" and the focus on Orthodox practices, a specific Jewish group, could be interpreted as coded language that reflects a broader concern of Jewish collective blame or targeting. This justification aligns with the JDA's definition of antisemitism, which includes discrimination against Jews based on their religious practices.

IHRA_Explanation: The tweet in question celebrates Jewish cultural heritage by mentioning a Ladino song performed by Sephardic Jews during quarantine. It highlights the involvement of Jewish artists and provides a link to the performance. There are no elements within the tweet that align with the IHRA definition of antisemitism, such as blaming Jews for conspiracies, denying the Holocaust, or making dehumanizing allegations about Jews. Instead, it appears to be a positive cultural expression that should not be considered antisemitic.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet celebrates a musical performance by Sephardic Jews during quarantine, highlighting their cultural contribution. It does not contain any discriminatory language or elements that link to antisemitic tropes. The focus is on cultural appreciation and unity, which aligns with the JDA's guidelines emphasizing non-discriminatory behavior towards Jews and their cultural activities.

Text: "Why do Jews reject Jesus?"\nThis one innocent question left the writer lost in thought, standing in the middle of the @IsraelMuseum. https://t.co/45J3loIJtt
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet asks, "Why do Jews reject Jesus?" While it addresses theological differences, the question's phrasing can be interpreted as targeting Jews negatively. It touches on stereotypes about Jewish rejection of Jesus and may imply a trivialization or censure of Jewish beliefs. This aligns with IHRA's examples of antisemitism, particularly in making mendacious or stereotypical allegations about Jews. Thus, the tweet is considered antisemitic as it can be seen as demeaning or using harmful stereotypes against Jewish people.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet poses a theological question about why Jews reject Jesus, which is a neutral inquiry based on religious beliefs and does not involve any discriminatory language or stereotypes. It does not meet the criteria for antisemitism as defined by the JDA, which focuses on discrimination against Jews as Jews. The content is not generalizing negatively about Jews but rather exploring a specific religious perspective.

Text: The use of the police this way against the Jews in New York is shocking and completely out of control.¬† And let‚Äôs all take note: this is being done at the direction of a liberal Democrat Governor. https://t.co/643hy9E1wr
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet describes police action against "the Jews" in New York and attributes it to a Democratic Governor. This targets Jewish individuals as a group, implying unfair treatment based on their identity, aligning with IHRA's definition of antisemitism which includes discriminatory actions against Jewish people.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet addresses an event involving police action against Jews in New York and criticizes the political direction behind it. It does not use classical antisemitic imagery, link Jews to evil forces, or imply inherent characteristics about Jewish people. Instead, it focuses on a specific incident of law enforcement behavior, making it a critique rather than an expression of antisemitism.

Text: If it makes you feel better to call me angry instead of listening to Jews of color go ahead but all you‚Äôre doing is proving my point and not dealing with the problem. - I‚Äôm just venting from a comment on the inter webs.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet expresses frustration toward someone who is not addressing an issue, particularly regarding their response to criticism. While it refers to "Jews of color," there's no indication of prejudice or stereotyping against Jewish people. The content focuses on interpersonal conflict rather than targeting Jews as a group or community. There's no mention of mendacious allegations, blaming Jews for societal issues, or other antisemitic tropes. Therefore, the tweet does not meet the criteria for antisemitism as defined by IHRA.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet refers to "Jews of color," which can be interpreted as targeting Jewish individuals based on their ethnic identity. This references racialized stereotypes, as mentioned in the JDA guidelines, specifically guidelines 3 and 4, which indicate that such statements can contribute to antisemitic behavior by linking Jewish people with negative characteristics. By focusing on Jewish ethnicity rather than addressing the issue, the tweet aligns with the definition of antisemitism as discrimination against Jews as Jews. Therefore, this tweet is considered antisemitic according to the JDA guidelines.

Text: @Kealan10573296 @IuvIand you say that as if we‚Äôre against jews and not the state of israel itself
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit antisemitic characteristics. It distinguishes between opposition to the state of Israel and Jews as individuals, aligning with permissible criticism of a country rather than hateful rhetoric against a people. It doesn't employ harmful stereotypes, deny historical atrocities, or target Jewish individuals collectively, thus adhering to IHRA's criteria without crossing into antisemitism.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet suggests that opposing the state of Israel is equivalent to opposing Jews themselves. This aligns with classical antisemitic notions that link Jews to evil forces or conspiracies (see guideline 2 and 3). By equating criticism of Israel with opposition to all Jews, the statement reinforces harmful stereotypes that Jews are inherently connected to the actions of the Israeli state, thereby targeting Jews as a group for their national identity. This violates the JDA's guidelines by treating Jews collectively responsible for the conduct of Israel (see guideline 7) and implying that Jewish individuals must defend or condone Israel's policies, which is not acceptable under the principle of equality (see guideline 10).

Text: Message from Louis Farakhan to the Jews\nhttps://t.co/nHeqPyWPzi
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet from Louis Farrakhan to the Jews links to a video that likely contains antisemitic content, such as conspiracy theories or dehumanizing remarks about Jews. Based on the IHRA definition and historical context of Farrakhan's statements, this constitutes antisemitism.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet from Louis Farrakhan referencing Jews and including a link that could promote negative stereotypes about Jewish wealth or influence aligns with the JDA's definition of antisemitism. As per guidelines 2, 3, and 4, such statements can be coded antisemitism by implying Jewish control over financial systems and using language that reinforces classical anti-Semitic tropes. Thus, this content qualifies as antisemitic under the JDA framework.

Text: Fox News literally compared Trump supporters to German Jews in the 1930s. They really don‚Äôt get it. Some of the biggest, unforgivable scumbags on the planet.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet compares Trump supporters to German Jews during the 1930s, drawing a parallel that equates a political group with a historically persecuted group. This comparison uses the severity of the Holocaust to demean another group, aligning with antisemitic tactics of dehumanization through mendacious comparisons and harmful stereotypes.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet compares Trump supporters to German Jews in the 1930s, drawing an analogy that links them to a historical period associated with antisemitism. This comparison invokes classical antisemitic stereotypes by suggesting a connection between a group and a context of Jewish persecution. Such comparisons can be seen as applying negative racialized imagery to Jews, falling under the category of indirect or coded antisemitic speech as outlined in the JDA guidelines. Therefore, the tweet is deemed antisemitic.

Text: @cynthiamckinney Depends on which Jews we‚Äôre speaking of. The fake Jews claiming to be Gods chosen, who have stolen and occupy the land in Israel? Or the actual Jews, Black/Melanated/Aboriginal Ppl here in Amerikkka?
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet employs language that separates Jews into "fake" and "real" categories, using terms like "stolen," "occupy," and conflating race with Jewish identity. These elements align with IHRA's definition of antisemitism by perpetuating harmful stereotypes and dehumanizing views about Jewish people, both in Israel and elsewhere.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet compares two groups of Jews, labeling one as "fake" who are accused of malicious actions like theft and occupation, while describing another group as real based on race. This comparison invokes antisemitic tropes by associating a group with negative stereotypes. It stereotypically links Jewish identity to unethical behavior, reinforcing harmful generalizations and stigmatization, thereby violating the JDA's guidelines against antisemitism.

Text: History will record how the European nations who collaborated or were silent in the mass murder of 6 million Jews suddenly leapt to eulogize the man who was trying to do the same. https://t.co/dgPHPrqQkX
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet references the Holocaust and compares it to another situation, which aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism. By using the Holocaust to criticize others, it reflects negatively on Jewish people and can incite hatred, thus falling under antisemitic rhetoric.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not explicitly target Jews or Jewish institutions. It uses historical context about European nations' inaction during the Holocaust and compares it to a man's actions, which is a political analogy rather than an attack on a specific group. While sensitive, the content does not involve negative stereotyping, incitement, or direct harm to Jews as per the JDA criteria.

Text: A museum in Lithuania dedicated to a Japanese diplomat who helped thousands of Jews flee Europe during World War II has been extended an economic lifeline by people in Japan (from @AP) \nhttps://t.co/rpd2rK3F7b #Holocaust
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit any elements of antisemitism as defined by IHRA. It highlights the positive role of a non-Jewish individual in saving Jews and acknowledges the importance of Holocaust remembrance through supporting a museum that commemorates such actions. There is no targeting of Jewish individuals, no stereotyping, nor any denial or trivialization of the Holocaust. Instead, it respectfully commemorates historical heroism and uses the hashtag to emphasize the significance of remembering the past.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit antisemitism as it neither discriminates against Jews nor uses stereotypes about them. Instead, it acknowledges a positive action by a Japanese diplomat who helped Jews during WWII, which is commendable and aligns with human rights principles.

Text: Buddhists, Christians, Jews and Muslims came together in post-election solidarity. https://t.co/LtflVVWxXB
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit antisemitic behavior. It instead highlights solidarity across different religious groups following an election, which promotes unity and respect. There are no elements of negativity towards Jews or any harmful stereotypes present in the statement.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet expresses solidarity among various religious groups following an election, celebrating their unity rather than targeting Jewish individuals or promoting antisemitic stereotypes. It does not align with any of the antisemitic examples listed in the JDA guidelines, such as collective responsibility, classical stereotypes, or denial of rights. Therefore, it is not considered antisemitic.

Text: ‚ÄòBelieve us‚Äô: Black Jews respond to the George Floyd protests, in their own words - Jewish Telegraphic Agency https://t.co/EjxjjuR7on a trav√©s de @jtanews
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet does not contain any content that fits the IHRA definition of antisemitism. It discusses how Black Jews are responding to George Floyd protests, focusing on their voices and perspectives. There is no element of hate towards Jews, nor any mendacious allegations, stereotypes, or blaming of Jews for wrongdoing. The context is about social justice and solidarity, not antisemitic content.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet in question does not exhibit antisemitic characteristics as per the JDA definition. It shares information from a respected Jewish news outlet, highlighting the perspectives of Black Jews on current events. There are no negative stereotypes, generalizations, or implications linking Jews to evil or conspiratorial activities. The content is informative and non-discriminatory, focusing on a specific group's response to societal issues without targeting Jews as a whole. Therefore, it does not qualify as antisemitic under the provided guidelines.

Text: The president of the United States telling U.S. Jews that they need to ‚Äúlove Israel‚Äù more. Nothing to see here. Back to Ilhan Omar and the left... https://t.co/JQ0kqmFwSY
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet in question contains elements that align with the IHRA definition of antisemitism. Specifically, it suggests that U.S. Jews should prioritize their love for Israel over other considerations, which reflects antisemitic stereotypes regarding Jewish loyalty and collective responsibility. By implying that Jewish individuals have a primary allegiance to Israel, it reinforces negative perceptions that can be considered antisemitic when taken out of context and analyzed through the lens of broader societal expectations of loyalty. This approach aligns with examples provided by IHRA, such as accusing Jews of having divided loyalties or holding them collectively responsible for actions of the Israeli state. Thus, the tweet is identified as antisemitic based on these criteria.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet in question implies that U.S. Jews should prioritize their loyalty to Israel over other loyalties based on their Jewish identity. This aligns with classical antisemitic tropes that link Jewish identity to a collective responsibility towards Israel, as outlined in the JDA guidelines (specifically points 6 and 7). By suggesting that Jewish Americans must "love Israel" more, the tweet reinforces a racialized expectation of loyalty, which falls under the definition of antisemitism as it targets Jews for their ethnic identity.

Text: On Holocaust Remembrance Day, we remember the six million Jews and other victims of Nazism.\n\nWe honor their memories by speaking out against anti-Semitism, injustice, and hatred in all forms. Never Again.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit any elements of antisemitism as defined by IHRA. It accurately mentions the Holocaust victims and advocates against prejudice, without making false accusations or using harmful stereotypes against Jews.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet correctly acknowledges the Holocaust and advocates against antisemitism without promoting stereotypes or linking Jews to negative traits, thus it is not antisemitic according to the JDA definition.

Text: "Imagine being a German in the 1930s and saying, 'I don't hate Jews and I have nothing against them and I'm a nice person. But I believe Hitler is doing great things for the economy and even though I don't condone everything he says, he still has my vote'."
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet compares supporting a controversial leader (Hitler) despite his rhetoric, which can be seen as ignoring or downplaying the gravity of the atrocities associated with him. This aligns with IHRA's example of denying the Holocaust or minimizing its significance, thus fitting the definition of antisemitism.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not reflect antisemitism as defined by the JDA. It is a hypothetical scenario comparing a person's stance in historical context and does not involve discrimination, prejudice, hostility, or violence against Jews. The content does not promote conspiracy theories, negative stereotypes, or deny the Holocaust; instead, it discusses political support without antisemitic intent. Thus, it falls outside the scope of antisemitism as defined.

Text: Zionism Is the movement that saved jews from anti semitism around the world and allowed them to get back to their original home, israel .\nTherefore, if you don't support Zionism you actually don't support jews right to defend themselves and have a safe home at their land . https://t.co/4Apn6ImQCX
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet contains language that equates opposition to Zionism with a lack of support for Jewish safety, which can be interpreted as targeting Jews with harmful stereotypes. It implies that without Zionism, Jews are vulnerable, linking antisemitism to their political stance. This aligns with IHRA's criteria of using stereotypes to blame or negatively impact the Jewish community.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet equates opposition to Zionism with not supporting Jews' right to defend themselves and find a safe home in Israel. This implies that only by supporting Zionism can Jews ensure their safety, which could be seen as coded language suggesting that not supporting Zionism is antisemitic. The connection between Zionism and Jewish protection is framed in a way that opposes criticism of Israeli policies, aligning with antisemitic tropes about Jewish collective responsibility and the need for protection through Zionist efforts. This aligns with JDA guidelines regarding coded antisemitism and collective responsibility, making the tweet potentially antisemitic.

Text: @shirahanau and why would anyone start a sentence with "Jews believe"?
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet "@shirahanau and why would anyone start a sentence with 'Jews believe'?" contains elements of antisemitism as per the IHRA definition. It implies a stereotypical view by focusing on Jewish beliefs in a manner that could reinforce negative stereotypes about Jews being controlling or pushy, aligning with IHRA's examples of harmful generalizations and stereotyping about Jewish people.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet in question, "@shirahanau and why would anyone start a sentence with 'Jews believe'?" does not meet the criteria for antisemitism as defined by the JDA. The statement is a neutral inquiry about how Jewish beliefs might be framed in speech, without any explicit or implicit harm to Jews or promotion of harmful stereotypes. It does not contain any elements such as sweeping negative generalizations, classical antisemitic tropes, or direct/indirect attacks on Jewish identity. Therefore, it does not qualify as antisemitic under the provided guidelines.
